HORSE SHOE STORE

The Only First-Class Store in the District.

We Are Right ON THE BOOM

This is no Bogus Sale. We are not Dissenting Partnership. Our Health is Good and Our Friends not Wary. We Don't Try to Give You Chestnuts.

But we can give you Goods Cheaper than any other House in town.

We have just received a Marvellous Stock—All

Fresh, Clean Goods!

LATEST STYLES, PATTERNS AND DESIGNS.

Which we will sell at cost, just to make things interesting for our friends.

Remember—we offer you old sizes, worn goods or winter stock, but new Spring Importations. Look at the following prices, and SMILE—

Gingham 10c. Grey Cottons 6, Prints 8,
White Cottons 8, Flannels 20, Plush $1.

Clothing—Men's Suits $5, Felt Hats 25c,

GROCERIES

Black Tea 25c, Tomatoes 20c, Corn 20c, California Fruit 45c, Dried Apples 12½c, Evaporated Apples 17c, Rice 8c, Matches 15c, Lollipops 6c, Oyster Fish 70c,

All Other Goods in Proportion.

Boots and Shoes at Cost.

THOS. O. DAVIS

'79. '88.

NOTICE!

T. J. AGNEW takes stock and Closes his Books on 30th of April. Parties indebted to him would greatly oblige by arranging their accounts previous to that date.

Until said date all goods will be greatly REDUCED FOR CASH.

BREAK PLOWS, CROSS PLOWS,

BOSS CHURNS, MILK PAILS, CREAMERS,
BUILDING HARDWARE

AT

J. M. CAMPBELL'S.

Never before heard of in Prince Albert. We are showing

MAGNIFICENT NEW SPRING GOODS

Far surpassing any previous seasons, both for richness of design and quality. The Variety of New Goods in Every Department is IMMENSE.

Call and Examine Our Stock

No trouble to show Goods.

J. M. CAMPBELL

DRY LUMBER.

MOORE & MACDOWALL

Wish to inform the Public that they have on hand and for sale a Half Million Feet of Dry Lumber, consisting of Matched, Dressed and Undressed.

Dressed Flooring, $48
Undressed do., 42
Dressed Siding, 48
Undressed do., 42
Sheeting, 30
Common Lumber, 35
Dimension do., 40

"Over 13 feet extra

Lath, '75 cts. per bundle.

Shingles, $6.50 per M.

We are prepared to Contract for Buildings as cheaply as any firm in Town.

Builders paying Cash or giving good security for LARGE Orders, will have a reduction made.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
MASONIC SERMON.

The following sermon was delivered by the Rev. Canon Flatt, D.D.G.M., at the northern of Kinloch Lodge, A.F.A., M.M., at Allens Church, and published at the request of the members present.

The sermon's text was taken from I Peter ii, chapter 50 verses. "Ye also, as lively stones, build yourselves up an house, an holy priesthood, to offer up spiritual sacrifices, acceptable to God through Jesus Christ."

It has been our custom, brothers, at this season of the year, to take a moment's glance at the condition of our temporal affairs, and to reflect upon the progress made by Prince Albert and his government in the advancement of the country.

The town certainly compares most favorably with many of the towns in Canada, and even with some of the villages of the United States. A good house has been built, and the town is now filled with commercial and agricultural produce. The future promises well, and we may look forward to prosperity for the future. The line of coal and iron will be completed, and the line of railway. I speak from personal knowledge, and I believe that within a few weeks thousands of tons of coal will be transported in the Territorial, with whom we have a close connection.

When the character of this section of the country is considered, it is evident that there will be rapid and extensive settlement. The town of New York is in regard to the future of the Eastern and Western Territories of Canada. The pioneer in speaking of the western territories is often met with a great expression to ideas that have been already formed and brought into being by those who have been engaged in the same work. We can apply only our own experience to the future of the Eastern and Western Territories of Canada. And while we are engaged in watching the mighty sweep of the map held out before us, we must not forget the strength, while the reverse of the westward movement is going on around us, and you by them are enabled to build your stable kingdom and to dwell in peace and prosperity for all time to come.

The impossible barrier of the Atlantic Ocean is broken down, and the way is open for the advance of the Eastern and Western Territories of Canada. The west is illimitable. States and provinces are being added to the Union, and back to those who are now taking possession of the new lands. The American continent is thus still more extended, and the advance of commerce and industry is still more rapid than ever before. The east will be compelled to surrender its supremacy, and the west will be called upon to take its place.

We must be prepared for the coming of the new era, and we must be ready to meet the challenges of the future. The west is the land of opportunity, and we must be prepared to take advantage of the opportunities that will come our way.

PRINCE ALBERT BREWERY.

Delivered to all Parts of the Town.

Pure and Sparkling.

BETTS & Gwynne.

R.C.W. & Co.

Clearing Sale!

We beg to notify the people of Prince Albert and vicinity that we have decided to dispose of our entire Stock of Ready Made Clothing, Dry Goods, Groceries, Glassware and Crockery.

At prices which cannot fail to satisfy intending purchasers.

All parties indebted to us will please settle at once as our books are closed.

R.C. Wigmore & Co.'s.

NEW GOODS

And Close Prices go to J.R. McPhail's.

The balance of our Trading Stores and Drums will be sold at cost for cash.

Boots and Shoes

A Large Stock. All Felt Goods must be cleared out.

If you want your money's worth in Hardware, Boots and Shoes, Clothing or Groceries, call on J.R. McPhail.

Robertson & Robertson,

Merchant Tailors
